issues.title: Missing Mandatory Reporting Requirements for Drug Offenses
issues.description: California law requires school officials to notify law enforcement within one school day when a student commits specified drug offenses on school grounds. Neither the BP nor AR contains the mandatory reporting requirements or the specific list of reportable drug offenses.

legal_citations.text: The principal of a school or the principal's designee shall, prior to the suspension or expulsion of any pupil, notify the appropriate law enforcement authorities of the county or city in which the school is situated of any acts of the pupil which may violate Section 245 of the Penal Code... or any acts which may involve the possession or sale of narcotics or of a controlled substance or of any other illegal act.

issues.required_language: The principal or designee shall notify appropriate law enforcement authorities within one school day of any acts involving the possession, use, or sale of controlled substances, alcohol, or intoxicants of any kind on school premises or during school-sponsored activities, as required by Education Code 48902.

issues.title: Missing Search and Seizure Procedures
issues.description: When dealing with suspected drug violations, school officials need clear guidance on their authority to search students, lockers, and property. Neither document provides procedures for conducting searches related to drug violations, which is essential for proper enforcement while protecting student rights.

legal_citations.text: No school employee shall conduct a search that involves removing or requiring a pupil to remove his or her clothing, except in an emergency threatening the immediate health or safety of the pupil or others.

issues.required_language: Searches of students suspected of drug violations shall be conducted in accordance with Education Code 49050 and constitutional requirements. Strip searches are prohibited except in emergencies threatening immediate health or safety. All searches must be reasonable in scope and based on reasonable suspicion.

issues.title: Missing Specific Disciplinary Consequences
issues.description: While the BP mentions suspension/expulsion may result from drug violations, neither document specifies the mandatory disciplinary actions required by Education Code for different types of drug offenses, particularly the mandatory recommendation for expulsion for certain drug sales.

legal_citations.text: The principal or the superintendent of schools shall recommend the expulsion of a pupil for any of the following acts committed at school or at a school activity off school grounds... Possessing, selling, or otherwise furnishing a firearm, knife, explosive, or other dangerous object, or unlawfully possessing, using, selling, or otherwise furnishing, or being under the influence of, a controlled substance, alcoholic beverage, or intoxicant of any kind.

issues.required_language: Students who unlawfully possess, use, sell, or furnish controlled substances, alcoholic beverages, or intoxicants, or who are under the influence of such substances on school grounds or at school activities shall be subject to suspension and may be recommended for expulsion as required by Education Code 48915.

issues.title: Missing Parent Notification Procedures
issues.description: The AR mentions that principals may notify parents when students are suspected of being under the influence, but lacks specific procedures and timelines for parent notification in drug-related incidents.

legal_citations.text: The principal of a school or the principal's designee shall notify the parent or guardian of a pupil by telephone or in person as soon as possible when the pupil is suspended.

issues.required_language: Parents/guardians shall be notified immediately by telephone when a student is suspected of being under the influence of drugs or alcohol, and written notification shall follow within 24 hours of any disciplinary action taken.

issues.title: Missing Due Process Procedures
issues.description: The documents reference disciplinary procedures but do not specify the due process requirements for drug-related suspensions and expulsions, including hearing rights and appeal processes.

legal_citations.text: The governing board shall expel any pupil found to have committed an expellable offense... The pupil shall be given written notice of the right to a hearing at least ten calendar days before the date of the hearing.

issues.required_language: Students facing suspension or expulsion for drug-related offenses shall receive due process including written notice, right to a hearing, right to representation, and right to appeal as specified in Education Code 48918 and related sections.
